snippet: Hydraulic fracking appears to cause smaller leaks of methane, a greenhouse gas, than the federal government estimates, according to a study released Monday.
abstract: Study conducted by University of Texas bolsters contention by advocates of hydraulic fracturing--and some environmental groups as well--that shale gas is cleaner and better than coal, at least until more renewable-energy sources are developed; concludes that drilling for shale gas through fracking appears to cause smaller leaks of greenhouse gas methane than federal government originally estimated; study appears in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
lead_paragraph: Hydraulic fracking appears to cause smaller leaks of methane, a greenhouse gas, than the federal government estimates, according to a study released Monday.

headline.main: Gas Leaks in Fracking Disputed in Study
headline.print_headline: Gas Leaks In Fracking Disputed In Study

keywords.value: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
keywords.name: organizations
